Topic.Title: Bond Offering?? LOL

Message.Msg: I don't think issuing bonds in itself is necessarily a negative. Many large companies issue debt to finance expansion. Amazon is building distribution centers so it makes sense to finance some of this with debt, particularly at the very favorable rates on offer now. It's completely another matter whether or not you think the expansion will be successful. To me the declining margins, increasing competition from many directions all in the context of an economy unlikely to grow much for some time points to an ill fated expansion. But clearly a lot of analysts and investors believe in the Amazon business model so it's not surprising that the debt issue would not be seen as a negative. In fact it fits right in with the "investing in the future" mantra they've been selling for the past several quarters.

Topic.Title: from zerohedge on the cybermonday nonsense:

Message.Msg: Racecap: I strongly suspect the tax deal will have an adjustment to LT capital gains holding period, taking it up from 1 to 2-3 for 20/23.8% and keeping current levels for 5+ years. What the Fed and the Admin are trying to do is to get people to invest in productive assets, not speculate on financial ones. Dividends will not get hit nearly as hard as cap gains -- it is basic political analysis. It has become the key source of income for the boomers and beyond and politicians cannot afford to alienate said group. But, financial speculators are universally despised by large swaths of the population. So, the people and institutions that hold this into the deal are likely to find themselves wishing they hadn't. I have to laugh that Amazon cancelled monthly Prime not longer after my post and then raised $3B after I had highlighted that capital would become far more expensive once its real cash flow situation becomes clear. I am right about the cash flow situation, but I have to credit GS with a nice save of a catastrophic implosion. For now. There still is event risk that can burn through that $3B in a few months tops... More on that another time because I think it is highly probably to occur within 12 months. One thing I did note on all the reports, it talked about Amazon's 3P growth (which was less than eBay's 3P growth), not Amazon's internal sales growth. People are assuming that the growth is on Amazon's entire sales, but the statistics are coming from Channel Advisor, which analyzes 3P sales. I'm going to keep tracking that, because if I am right that it is 3P and not Amazon total growth, people are going to be in for one helluva shock and selloff... Tech

Topic.Title: from zerohedge on the cybermonday nonsense:

Message.Msg: I strongly suspect speculation in financial assets will get hit hardest in the tax changes. LT cap gains will require 2-3 year holding (and still likely go up to 20/23.8%) and require 5 years to get to current levels. Dividends will not see the increases being feared. It is basic political analysis. Large swaths of the US population currently or will soon depend upon dividends for income. In contrast, financial speculators are widely disliked and an easy target. Besides, what the Fed and Admin are really trying to do is encourage ownership of productive assets (those that actually produce income streams and not simply revenue streams...). GS made a nice save today. I was (am) right about the cash flow trends for Amazon. But, cancelling monthly prime and raising $3B bought some time.

Message.Msg: What conspiracy? My read is ZH simply saying Ben is using the only tool he can to manage deflation without it going into a self reinforcing spiral, printing money to prop asset values while everyone loses real purchasing power and wealth in real terms... More and more are beginning to understand its limitations. It would have worked 20 years ago, but income and wealth are sufficiently skewed that only a Steve Keen like QE for the people has a chance... The real fun will be seeing what happens to deductions. If they are capped too low, you can say goodbye to the housing recovery and consumer confidence...
